1.1 Company Profile

The company began with a view to providing software to up and coming businesses in the retail industry. Based at the University of York, we are a small company consisting of 10 highly competent undergraduate employees who shall aim for high quality work in all areas, providing loyal customer service and superlative, round the clock product support.??

Team Members:

                                   

Figure 1: Company Organisational Structure (Get from QA Manual)

1.2 Vision

●           To bring software to play a more major role in the modern day supermarket

●           To enhance the everyday shopping experience

●           To provide a consistently high quality of customer service

●           To produce cost-effective and well-designed products

Our first project has been designing a supermarket application

 and how it has worked, highlighting (and providing links to) the appropriate documents.

1.3 Goal

Our goal by the time of this report was to have a product which was easy to use, looked appealing and fulfilled the functionality that we promised by this stage.

We planned to do this using an Agile, XP, Test Driven Methodology.

This approach was vindicated in two instances:

  1. The dramatic shift in our program to start using a SQL database at the end of the Easter holidays did not pose much problem due to our Agile mindset
  2. When merging our branches together, the tests were invaluable in providing a quick and thorough check of the merged code

Initially, this strategy, in particular Test Driven Development (TDD), took some getting used to. Over time however, the advantages became clear and the strategy developed into a routine.

Relevant Documents: Perhaps our github repository & database ??

1.4 Roadmap

The first task from a programming point of view was to refamiliarise ourselves with Java, Agile practices, Test Driven Development. This was accomplished by the writing of a coding standards document, the provision of ebooks and providing useful links either in e-mails or documentation i.e. the “Further Details” section of the Coding Standards Document??Link)

Research into other areas, such as: XML Parsing, Client-Server Communications and GUI Design were also deemed necessary. It was decided that splitting into 3 broadly different programming areas: (GUI, Control & Internal Data Structures [IDS]), each the responsibility of a programming manager (Arne Sandschulte, Prashant Chakravarty & Alasdair Munday respectively) was a suitable structure for our company.

Since our human resources consisted of ten people and XP practice calls for pair programming, we decided to split up into 5 pairs (teams). Two areas (initially GUI & IDS) would be assigned a pair of teams, while the final team had just one team. The entire programming section was under the oversight of the Design & Integration Manager (Thomas Lea)

The tasks were split up between the three programming groups as appropriate. This can be seen in the “Software Tasks Week 6 Document” (link this text??).

Programming Managers meetings were held regularly (frequency??) although they were not all minuted. In the summer term, these meetings were more in the form of get togethers in the laboratory rather than formal meetings.

1.5 QA Metrics

As defined in the QA Manual, and elaborated on in the Individual Reports, each role had a set of QA metrics with which to measure the success of that role. A brief summary is given below:

  1. Coding standards were laid out in a document, and all code was quality checked by a team member other than the authors
  2. Weekly meetings were held which ensured deadlines were kept to and the impact of team issues were minimal
  3. All team members were easily accessible in person or by e-mail meaning any misunderstandings or confusion was quickly cleared up

Relevant Documents:
